repnme.cdata!:
Bulgaria - Environmental Remediation Pilot
            Project; and Environmental and Privatization Support
            Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Environmental
            Remediation Pilot Project for Bulgaria are as follows:
            outcome was satisfactory; risk to the development outcome
            was negligible/low; Bank performance was satisfactory; and
            Borrower performance was also satisfactory. Ratings for the
            Environmental and Privatization Support Adjustment Loan
            (EPSAL) Project for Bulgaria are as follows: outcome was
            satisfactory; risk to the development outcome was moderate;
            Bank performance was satisfactory; and Borrower performance
            was moderately satisfactory. Lessons learned from the
            projects included: a development policy loan supporting
            privatization with environmental remediation should include
            strong measures by the Government to monitor and reward
            compliance (or punish non-compliance) to ensure that
            remediation and compliance plans are completed on schedule.
            In the EPSAL, even though all of the policy conditions were
            met and the remediation plan's (RPs) were signed, the
            achievements in terms of implementation of the plans, along
            with their environmental results, were mixed. Even in
            well-prepared environmental impact assessments (EIAs), it is
            difficult to include sufficient detail in the technical
            specifications of remediation investments. Modifications in
            design and re-negotiations during implementation should be
            anticipated, and possibly reflected in a longer project
            implementation period and higher than normal contingency
            funds. Even when the state assumes responsibility for
            remediating past environmental damages of state-owned
            enterprises (SOEs), setting a cap on the state's
            liability creates risk for potential investors and delays
            during re-negotiations. The possibility of letting the state
            assume more of the risk for additional remediation costs
            should be considered.

Bulgaria - Environmental and Privatization
            Support Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability highly likely, and institutional development
            impacts are substantial. The experience of the project
            demonstrates that there are at least four major factors that
            need to be in place to succeed in privatizing environmental
            sustainability: Government commitments, to foster inclusion
            of environmental considerations in sales negotiations, and
            agreement; appropriate legal, and regulatory framework;
            sufficient institutional capacity, and commitment for
            environmental enforcement; and, commitments by new owners to
            sustainable environmental management. Specific report
            examples, reinforce the above mentioned statements.

repnme.cdata!:
Bulgaria - Environment and Privatization
            Support Adjustment Loan Project (EPSAL) : release of the
            third tranche

abstracts.cdata!:
The progress made by the Government of
            Bulgaria on the Environment and Privatization Support
            Adjustment Loan (EPSAL) EPSAL implementation was
            satisfactory. Although there were delays in meeting the
            remaining loan conditions by July 30 ,2003 for disbursement
            of tranche three, the Government demonstrated consistent and
            sound efforts to overcome the delays in the ongoing
            remediation programs, eliminate formal obstacles, and
            accelerate implementation in good partnership with
            participating enterprises.  Progress toward meeting the
            specific targets for tranche three release include: issuance
            of and compliance with pilot integrated environmental
            permits; satisfactory progress made in implementation of
            framework remediation plans and compliance plans; fulfilled
            its obligations under the Execution Agreements concluded
            with buyers of enterprises; maintained inter-agency
            coordinating body with membership satisfactory to the Bank
            to oversee implementation of the EPSAL; mitigation measures
            taken as identified during EIA public consultation process
            or EIA monitoring activities; and payments were made from
            the remediation account for activities under the framework
            remediation plans above an aggregate amount acceptable to
            the Bank

repnme.cdata!:
Bulgaria - Environment and Privatization
            Support Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Environment and Privatization
            Support Adjustment Loan Project, will assist the Government
            of Bulgaria in achieving environmental improvements, and
            will support the privatization of highly polluting
            enterprises, in line with the European Union (EU)
            environmental requirements. Comprehensive reforms of the
            country's environmental policies, will be supported,
            along with the establishment of a satisfactory framework for
            inclusion of environmental issues into the privatization
            process, and, measures to accelerate the implementation of
            the EU Directive on Integrated Pollution Prevention and
            Control, will be included. Nonetheless, risks may affect
            project implementation, much dependent on the successful
            privatization program of large enterprises, an achievement
            largely supported by the Second Financial and Enterprise
            Sector Loan; and, pressures to complete individual
            privatization deals, may delay commitments to include
            environmental issues into the privatization process.
            However, the benefits of improving environmental conditions,
            protecting human health, and sensitive ecosystems, mitigates
            the risks.
